title: Riot talk to me; You're about to lose a player since season 1 (not that any of that matters to you)
body: Why does Riot constantly tend to take what random people report into account when there is no time for the tribunal to even review the case before they ban players? I just got out of a game and was DC'd only to find out that Riot had banned my account from today until the 20th! I said nothing that wasn't true to my players and the game was a decent one AND I had several games before the one riot deemed unsportsmanlike without any incident. I would much rather if someone from riot would actually talk to me (which I understand they have many people who are in the same issue as I am and they don't have enough employees to hit each person) but they just ban people for no reason and without just cause. Riot PLEASE talk with me and solve this issue I've been playing since season one and have spent PLENTY of money on your game and spread the word of it across many different forums if you don't care about us  players then just say so,I'll stop sending new players to you and I'll go find some other game to play (I spend a LOT of time on FFXIV instead of your game that hates their player base); if you actually care about my service give me a heads up, but I get the feeling you don't give not one but TWO fucks about us as a community. I'll be awaiting ANYONE from riot to respond (which I already know you won't since you're "sooooooooo busy")

replies.body:
Hiya! 

While I don't have access to your account, so I can't pull up chat logs or the like, I can shed a bit of light on the player reform system that we've most recently put in place. 

> Why does Riot constantly tend to take what random people report into account when there is no time for the tribunal to even review the case before they ban players?

The system has set up to validate reports, which means that false reports will not count against you. When this system was initially rolled out, the team handling the new reform system reviewed the few several thousand cases the system reviewed to ensure it was working properly (not false banning, etc.). 

>  I just got out of a game and was DC'd only to find out that Riot had banned my account from today until the 20th! 

If you're curious about your ban, please feel free to submit a ticket to [Player Support](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new). They'd be able to look into your account a bit more and provide more information. 

You should have also received a reform card, sent to your email, which shares your chat logs, as well as the resulting punishment. 

>  I said nothing that wasn't true to my players and the game was a decent one AND I had several games before the one riot deemed unsportsmanlike without any incident.

While what you're saying may have been true - someone doing poorly, not grouping etc., were you saying it in a manner that was constructive? While I can understand frustration in game - I think we've all been there - there's a right and a wrong way to call a teammate out when they're doing poorly. Phrases like, "WTF are you doing Teemo, group up" isn't optimal, whereas something like, "Hey Teemo, we really need to fight as five, can you stop pushing top and group mid?" is something that is much more constructive.

> if you don't care about us players

We do care! Unfortunately, there are a lot more of you than there are of us, which makes one on one communication a bit harder than it used to be. 

If you'd like more information on the new player reform system, you can check out Lyte's post [here](http://euw.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/player-behavior/new-player-reform-system-heads-testing). There's also [an article](http://euw.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/player-behavior/player-behavior-design-values-punishment) on our values when it comes to punishments, if you're curious about that, too. 

Hope this helps a bit!

I still want to believe that False reports dont aid in punishment, but when punishment is gated by volume of reports, you only need a small handful of valid reports along with some false ones to get punishment.  I cant trust that the automated system can discern from the two.

It's not gated by volume of reports, but by relative report rate. We could both get reported in 100 games, but if you've only played 300 total, and I've played 1000 total, there's a **huge** difference in the rate of those reports.

I don't know what the threshold for that is (though it used to be somewhere between 12-25%), but it's still a factor. And that's not accounting for report weight, which is still totally a thing - demonstrably false reports cause a player's future reports to actually be worth less in determining whether a case is built.

And, finally, there's the review step. Simply because there's no *person* handling reviews doesn't mean that chat logs and game-states aren't being reviewed at all. The chat-detection algorithm that handles these reviews is actually pretty impressively accurate.

All of which means this: a full run of false reports should never hurt you (I've never heard of anyone receiving a sanction who had ONLY false reports against them). However, false reports **may** push you over the edge into a review, which may lead to a sanction based on the behaviors indicated by the *valid* reports.

But you can't do anything about false reports. No one can. Avoiding *valid* reports, on the other hand, is entirely in your hands.

the problem is that with the new system its less rate and more volume due to wanting to expedite the process and punish sooner, especially with those who already had been punished before.

Theoretically you can get punished for 1 valid report and the rest being false

>
>  They lessened the threshold for punishments so that punishment was more clear.  

I'm not sure how making punishments occur at a lower threshold would make them more clear. I *do* understand how making sure that the punishment comes as quickly as possible after the final trigger does. But that's not really the same thing at all.

> I just know that alot of people are getting not only quick punishment for high volume reported games

Without access to the actual report logs, I'm at a loss as to how you know this.

> but also they are getting chain punished. (for me i was punished 4 games after finishing a 10 game chat restriction.  That means it generated a case in no more than 14 games, and i was trying real hard to not talk, i know i slipped up, but i dont think the couple slip ups warranted another restriction)

Chained chat restrictions are a whole different thing. Since the inception of the chat restriction system, it's performed a new review at the end of a set of restrictions, as a sort of "checkup" to see what the player's standing is.

This new review doesn't require any further reports - though reports probably don't help any.

In order for punishments to come out more quickly, you need the threshold for triggering review to be lowered.  Slapping a person's wrist 3 days after they make the mistake isn't clear.  Doing it 20 minutes after they do, is a bit more clear, you can realize you did 'something' wrong that day, rather than.  I guess i did something wrong the past 3 days, or weeks or months.

Based on people's complaints and personal experience across my own 2 accounts and watching friends/streamers/etc.  You can trigger a warning within 1 game, that means somewhere between 1-9 reports (assuming average report weight) can trigger the pop-up, i dont know if the system can give its own report or if the automated system even looks at the logs for high volume report games.

As for the chain punishment, I am talking strictly outside of the 'checkup', because those happen near instantly.  My last one happened over the span of 2-3 weeks as my game volume dropped.  I finished my restrictions, and played 4 games over ~2 weeks, and the 4th game triggered another restriction set.  If it were a 'checkup' i would have received it before the 2nd game.

> [{quoted}](name=Rueian,realm=NA,application-id=cIfEodbz,discussion-id=z2zerNui,comment-id=00060000000000000001000000000000,timestamp=2015-07-10T06:26:53.486+0000)
>
> In order for punishments to come out more quickly, you need the threshold for triggering review to be lowered.  Slapping a person's wrist 3 days after they make the mistake isn't clear.  Doing it 20 minutes after they do, is a bit more clear, you can realize you did 'something' wrong that day, rather than.  I guess i did something wrong the past 3 days, or weeks or months.

You're misrepresenting the goal, which was to ensure that punishments came out more quickly **after they were triggered**. Decreasing how long it takes to trigger them has nothing to do with that.

> Based on people's complaints and personal experience across my own 2 accounts and watching friends/streamers/etc.  You can trigger a warning within 1 game, that means somewhere between 1-9 reports (assuming average report weight) can trigger the pop-up, i dont know if the system can give its own report or if the automated system even looks at the logs for high volume report games.

The warnings aren't triggered by report volume, either. They never have been, and they haven't been touched in the reworks. Again, without some actual *evidence* of the number of reports - i.e. access to the report logs - I don't see how you can make assumptions like this.

> As for the chain punishment, I am talking strictly outside of the 'checkup', because those happen near instantly.  My last one happened over the span of 2-3 weeks as my game volume dropped.  I finished my restrictions, and played 4 games over ~2 weeks, and the 4th game triggered another restriction set.  If it were a 'checkup' i would have received it before the 2nd game.

Perhaps. But the system's not binary. It operates on a scale - so it's perfectly possible that the checkup determined you were just this side of negative, and then over the course of those 4 games, you received enough *reported* games to put you back over the threshold.

When they triggered, and how long they took to process were both issues.  If you get a case that is built up for over a month, that is part of the issue.  I remember old tribunal cards that had games spanning over very long time frames.  Punishing a person for something they did months ago isn't clear.  Having the ability to trigger instantly (automated chat scanning) along with report based triggered reviews allow the machine to hopefully create a context for negative behavior.  This is the intent of the system.  It speeds up punishment on All sides.

Riot will never give out the information for us to understand the system that deeply, because they fear it will be abused.  All we can work with is circumstantial evidence across a large base of players.  As i continue to gather data from players along with my own experiences, i've put together that what it takes to trigger a case, is ALOT smaller than before.  the use of 'volume' is not meant to be taken out of context, i know it is still a ratio, but the minimum number of games needed to generate a warning is tiny now.  And once you have a couple warnings your account is considered in negative standing and will start getting restrictions, and from that point you get even harsher judgements from an automated system.  I use volume, because rather than it being less than 25% report rate over 10-20 games, it feels more like less than 3 reports in a game, but if you are reported 2 games in a row you get a warning.

See given that example that means that over 14 games i was able to generate a case.  Even with 10 of them chat restricted.  And i'm not talking about behavior i'm talking that the system is just so heavily aggressive and false reports make it even harder to "reform" as a player with a negative standing account.  And if a false report helps punish a seemingly valid case, that reporter is empowered not for the report in his game, but for bringing someone who was toxic in a game he didn't even experience to be punished.

I don't see it that way. I also recognize that changing the system in such a way opens the system to a known and recognized form of abuse - one that players believed for **years** to be a concern. Which is more than counter-productive, it's actually *destructive* to the very purpose of the system.

Beyond that, due the the way the system functions now (that is to say, the immediate response after triggering, including a log of the triggering event), the prior concern about how long had passed since the various games in the Reform Card isn't particularly relevant. The logs shown to the player will *always* be relevant, because they're recent.

As focused as Riot is on accuracy with these systems, I can't imagine that they'd sacrifice that **and** invite abuse, all in the name of expedience.

> Riot will never give out the information for us to understand the system that deeply, because they fear it will be abused.  All we can work with is circumstantial evidence across a large base of players.  As i continue to gather data from players along with my own experiences, i've put together that what it takes to trigger a case, is ALOT smaller than before.  the use of 'volume' is not meant to be taken out of context, i know it is still a ratio, but the minimum number of games needed to generate a warning is tiny now.  And once you have a couple warnings your account is considered in negative standing and will start getting restrictions, and from that point you get even harsher judgements from an automated system.  I use volume, because rather than it being less than 25% report rate over 10-20 games, it feels more like less than 3 reports in a game, but if you are reported 2 games in a row you get a warning.

The minimum number of games needed to generate a warning is - and always has been - variable. They don't trigger at a fixed threshold, but rather based on spikes in reported games against the player - that is, if my normal report rate is 1%, and over the next day, it jumps to 5%, I'll receive a warning. But if my normal rate is 10%, I wouldn't see one unless I saw a spike somewhere above that (probably in the neighborhood of 13-15%).

There's absolutely no evidence to support any indication that the basic functions of the systems have changed. And I've yet to see any *credible* evidence that decision-making thresholds have changed. If you **have** actual evidence, please feel free to present it.

They said that they were going to make the system more strict as a first step, so much so that they wanted to heavily watch the system for outliers. The issue I have is as we now are judged by a machine, if that machine becomes compromised in any degree the greater the chance for false judgement in the future.

Imagine it this way, say you are stealing from stores.  And they need 4 reports to trigger building a case,  you steal from 3 of 10 stores, but  1 store you didn't steal from reported that you did.  Given leagues system, that false reporter gets a stronger say in people doing wrong.

If a false reporter somehow ends up with a strong report value, they can effectively report and always be right even if they are lieing.

As things stand there arnt any checks or balances except for very rare screening of cases and having to navigate the very poorly handled support  system.  The suspended/banned tickets do not get handled at all well, and as a unintentionally toxic player (emotional control issues), I'm going to go out and say now, if you are punished even once, the community and in some cases riot itself treats you as less than human.

Presuming that it happens often enough to be worth significant concern is silly.

Iterative development is an important part of developing massive systems like this. As you build a piece, you put it into place, tweak the system-as-implemented to ensure it all keeps working, and then build the new piece.

In all likelihood, they were working on this in conjunction with the rest of the system, but before they could add finishing touches and put it in place, they needed to make sure that everything else wasn't going to break from the *last* addition.

Oh, that's unfortunate.

I hoped after 15 months, I'd learn what I did wrong.

In my experience, it's usually general negativity that leads to repeating chat restrictions. That's what makes it so hard for the player to recognize, because it's not so much about what the person says as *how* they say it - they aren't bashing or berating or belittling, or anything obvious. They're just... perpetually negative towards people.

So the best bet for avoiding them is the flip-side of that. Be positive, encouraging, and inclusive. That's a difficult flip, though, and positivity isn't *necessary* - just faster.

Civility is also an effective way to avoid restrictions. Say nothing that isn't relevant to the game, and avoid emotional language. Be indirect, and avoid referring to any specific person whenever possible. In short: be clear, concise, and mechanical in your communication.

Worst case, you can submit a Support ticket about it, or post @Lyte on Reddit. Being polite and precise about what you're after tends to yield good results.

This forum isn't where you go to get a response from Riot. There are Rioters who read the boards, but they can't possibly reply to everyone who asks. Under "Description", say *"I recently received a ban for behavior but I did not receive any detailed information. If you look, I'm sure you'll see that I haven't done anything wrong.
